OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Removed the pull outs (labeled Compact bone) from the right of the main bone image, but kept the blood cells; kept same version of main bone image but made the blood vessels come out of the bone; moved the cut-out portion of the bone (labeled Blood vessels in bone marrow ) to the right side of the main bone image and the blood cells to the right of the cut-out; made the cut-out portion of the bone come from more towards the end of the bone so that it shows more spongy bone; made spongy bone trabecular in cut-out; changed image title to Bone Anatomy

Changed label to Spongy bone (contains red marrow); added an inset for Spongy bone and included the labels Blood vessel and Blood stem cell, Red blood cells, and White blood cells pointing to the inset; removed the different white blood cell types; added separate insets for Blood vessels in bone marrow and Compact bone; and made change from red marrow to yellow marrow more gradual in main bone figure

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Anatomy of the bone; drawing shows spongy bone, red marrow, and yellow marrow. A cross section of the bone shows compact bone and blood vessels in the bone marrow. Also shown are red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, and a blood stem cell.

Captions.MediaCaption: Anatomy of the bone. The bone is made up of compact bone, spongy bone, and bone marrow. Compact bone makes up the outer layer of the bone. Spongy bone is found mostly at the ends of bones and contains red marrow. Bone marrow is found in the center of most bones and has many blood vessels. There are two types of bone marrow: red and yellow. Red marrow contains blood stem cells that can become red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets. Yellow marrow is made mostly of fat.

ProposedUse.Summary: Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Treatment
